Meijer Central Kitchen, located at 536 North Main Street, Middlebury, Indiana is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety.

Meijer Central Kitchen processes ready to eat foods and distribution.  The facility includes processing tanks, piping, packaging equipment, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, an Ammonia refrigeration engine room, boilers, and miscellaneous utilities. 

The refrigeration system required for our production process necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan.  The refrigeration system contains 34,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  This surpasses the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds outlined in Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program regulations.

Meijer Central Kitchen has implemented numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.

Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. 

Meijer Central Kitchen has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library consisting of five numbered volumes

, as well as reference materials. Volume numbers are assigned to sets of reference manuals, such as the Operation and Maintenance manuals. The library also incorporates the use of video tapes and computerized tests.

VOLUME I of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates mainly policies and hazard data, the following policies are included in Volume I:

Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.

Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).

Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.

Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.

Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.

Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc..) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Quality Assurance Manager.

VOLUME II incorporates information on the specific system components of the production area equipment. This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components.

VOULME III incorporates a complete valve list,

process and instrumentation diagrams, flow schematics, and other drawings pertinent to the refrigeration equipment. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system. Process and Instrumentation Diagrams are included for the individual refrigeration system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire refrigeration system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate refrigeration equipment in the building.

VOLUME IV incorporates a complete set of standard operating procedures for the production area equipment. Describing the proper steps for preparing components for initial start-up, re-starting components, monitoring normal operation, shutting down as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pump out procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system components. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.

VOLUME V contains Operation and Maintenance Information for the refrigeration equipment including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventative maintenance procedures.

Process Hazard Analysis was performed in October 2006.  The PHA highlighted some deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of priority (Injuries to personnel). 

Meijer Central Kitchen also

incorporates additional safety items such as labeling, tagging of all ammonia system valves and components. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

Meijer Central Kitchen, Middlebury, Indiana. is a food based processing and distribution facility. The facility incorporates a standard evaporation and compression closed loop ammonia refrigeration system. 



SUMMARY OF THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Meijer Central Kitchen has had no accident(s) in the past five years involving ammonia.


DESCRIPTION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

In the event that an ammonia leak is detected employees are to notify a member of management .

1)  immediately notify team leaders

2)  as quickly as can safely be done, evaluate the situation.

3)  evacuate all team members and secure the location as much as possible,  always based on good life safety practices.

4)  notify 911 as appropriate.

5)  only in the event that it is determined necessary to save a life.

6)  local emergency trained personnel will be used to resolve. Any situation which we believe is beyond our building team member's.

7)  personal life safety will always be the determining factor.

8)  notification of appropriate governmental agencies and off-site responders; 

9)  notification of appropriate corporate personnel.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Meijer Central Kitchen is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Meijer Central Kitchen to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
